<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of need_100_continue:
```c
static bool
need_100_continue (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  const char *expect;

  if (! MHD_IS_HTTP_VER_1_1_COMPAT (connection->rq.http_ver))
    return false;

  if (0 == connection->rq.remaining_upload_size)
    return false;

  if (MHD_NO ==
      MHD_lookup_connection_value_n (connection,
                                     MHD_HEADER_KIND,
                                     MHD_HTTP_HEADER_EXPECT,
                                     MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ ( \
                                       MHD_HTTP_HEADER_EXPECT),
                                     &expect,
                                     NULL))
    return false;

  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_ (expect,
                               "100-continue"))
    return true;

  return false;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (0 == connection->rq.remaining_upload_size)
    return false;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 14.3 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Not violated: the controlling expression compares the runtime value connection->rq.remaining_upload_size against 0, so it is not invariant. (A violation would occur only if remaining_upload_size were a compile‑time constant/always the same value, e.g. #define or const known to be 0.)
